Piss queen with an anal rising

If you add any sort of flexible component to a regression model, you’re gonna need a bathtub and a change of clothes.

Gaussian Processes
Author

Dan Simpson

Published

November 7, 2022

Table of contents

  • The problem

I am not a causal queen. I’m sorry. I love you all. I love your horrendous notation. I love your uncheckable conditions. I get positively giddy when someone says “efficient”. I love youse all.

But I am not a causal queen.

So, of course, I’m going to foolishly spend a few thousand words on some causal-adjacent topics. Because, my brothers nad sisters in Christ, if you like using things like Gaussian processes and multilevel models (and I like using things like Gaussian processes), you need to think a lot more about this stuff than you do if you’re just doing regression models.

I guess, most of all, this bit can be read as a disclaimer. But we shall see.

The problem

One of the most common tasks in statistics is linear1 regression: the fine art of putting a straight line through some data. This typically takes the form \[ y_i \sim N(\beta_0 + \beta_1 x_{1i} + \beta_2 x_{2i} + \cdots + \beta_p x_{pi}, \sigma^2), \] where \(\beta_0\) is the intercept, \(\beta_j\) is the weight of the covariate \(x_j\), and \(\sigma\) is a thing that no one cares about until2 they need a p-value.

We all know how to interpret \(\beta_j\): it is the amount we expect the average of \(y_i\) to change if we increase \(x_j\) by one unit and leave everything else fixed. That is \[ \beta_j = \mathbb{E}(y \mid X_j = x_j+1, X_{-j} = x_{-j}) - \mathbb{E}(y \mid X = x). \]

That has not, does not, and will not stop people from interpreting \(\beta_j\) any damn way they please.

The whole reason that we have causal analysis is that this quantity isn’t really very interesting. It is … unusual … to be able to change only one variable in your regression. For example if \(x_1\) and \(x_2\) are correlated, changing \(x_1\) will necessarily change \(x_2\). So instead we want the unconditional equivalent of \(\beta_j\), which is the quantity \[ \mathbb{E}(y \mid X_j = x_j+1) - \mathbb{E}(y \mid X_j = x_j). \]

(If you’ve ever wondered if causal analysis is just predictive inference, you can see here that it almost is. The difference is that you need to model more than you ordinarily would.)

This quantity is hard to estimate because it requires us to marginalise3 the distribution of the other covariates, which I’ll occasionally write as \(x_{-j}\).

To do this, you need some sort of model for the entire4 joint distribution \(p(y, x)\). This is very hard to do.

To get around that, all of the causal modelers make some assumptions about the relationships between the covariates and how they relate to the response. Sometimes, people write this as a DAG5 and all power to them. But just as often, people just write them down, give them soft-sounding names like SUTVA6.

But that’s not really the topic of this post.

I just want to talk about what happens to the \(\beta_j\)s when you change your model to \[ y_i \mid x_i, \beta, u, \sigma \sim N(x_i^T\beta + u_i, \sigma^2 ), \] where the random effect \(u_i \sim N(0, Q^{-1})\) for some matrix \(Q\).

Footnotes

  1. and logistic etc but like this is a blog↩︎

  2. and even then they do a sneaky \(\sigma^2\) estimate. Frequentist statistics is in love with secrets.↩︎

  3. average over↩︎

  4. This is in direct opposition to regression modelling where you only need a model for the conditional mean \(\mathbb{E}(y \mid x)\) (or the Bayesian equivalent where you need a model for the conditional distribution \(p(y \mid x)\)).↩︎

  5. TikZ is my passion↩︎

  6. The Stable Unit Treatment Value Assumption, which is the assumption that the value of the unit treatment is stable.↩︎
